![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/94o6H.png)

and I am sure that that file does not exist in the project because I just deleted it. Also when I try to look for that file it does not exist.

\#\#\# Top Answer: Try this:

1. go to the folder were the old image was and place it there again.
2. go to xcode and click on add files to xcode, select the old image again and add it.
3. remove the image form xcode both its reference and physically.
4. add the new image (you can drag and drop to xcode or use add files to xcode)

Hope this helps

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: When replacing images in an Xcode project, you encounter an error stating that a file you've deleted still exists. What is the correct sequence of steps to resolve this issue and successfully replace the image?

A) 1. Delete the image from Xcode
   2. Add the new image to the project folder
   3. Drag and drop the new image into Xcode
   4. Clean and rebuild the project

B) 1. Temporarily restore the old image to its original location
   2. Add the old image back to Xcode
   3. Remove the old image from Xcode (reference and physical file)
   4. Add the new image to Xcode

C) 1. Clear Xcode's derived data
   2. Force quit Xcode and restart
   3. Delete the image from the project folder
   4. Add the new image through "Add files to Xcode"

D) 1. Remove the image reference from Xcode
   2. Delete the image file from the project folder
   3. Restart Xcode
   4. Add the new image using "Add files to Xcode"

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct sequence is option B, which follows the steps outlined in the top answer from StackExchange. This method addresses the issue of Xcode retaining references to deleted files by first restoring the old image, re-adding it to Xcode, then properly removing it both from Xcode and the file system. This process clears any lingering references before adding the new image, preventing the error shown in the question. Options A, C, and D skip crucial steps or use methods that don't directly address the root cause of the error, making them less likely to resolve the issue effectively.

\#\#\# User: I understand the concept of a negative voltage. Ground is a reference point and it's easy to get a negative voltage if your ground reference is above earth ground. Does a differential power supply actually produce a negate voltage (referenced to earth ground) or does it just use a voltage offset from ground as a ground reference.

For example a \+\-5V power supply can easily be created by using two voltages (\+10V, \+5V) and GND. If you use \+5V as ground, it will make \+10V the \+5 equivalent. GND will become the \-5V equivalent. The problem with such a circuit is that ground isn't compatible with earth ground. For example you can't then tie your newly created (\+5V offset) ground to earth ground without creating a short circuit.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Voltage may be interpreted as a measure of the potential energy of a theoretical test charge divided by its magnitude (dimensionally, volts are joules per coulomb). As with many potentials in classical physics, this is a relative quantity, meaning that your measurement of a potential is between some two points or states.

Physically, there is nothing incompatible with the idea that the relative potential of some point P is negative when referenced to earth ground, or any other reference for that matter. All it means is that a theoretical positive charge would lose some amount of potential energy when moving from your earth ground or reference to P.

We can easily realize this by demonstration with a number of examples that should prove that there's "truly" such a thing as a negative DC voltage with reference to earth ground:

1. Electrochemical: Suppose that the ground pin at left is physically earthed by bonding it to earth ground (e.g. by burying an electrode into wet dirt outdoors). The `-5V` label clearly and demonstrably has a negative voltage with respect to earth ground.

![schematic](https://i.stack.imgur.com/pFGkQ.png)

[simulate this circuit](/plugins/schematics?image=http%3a%2f%2fi.stack.imgur.com%2fpFGkQ.png) – Schematic created using [CircuitLab](https://www.circuitlab.com/)

2. Charge pumps and switching regulators: There are a number of circuit topologies that can produce a negative voltage given a positive supply. The simplest would be a charge pump, where a capacitor is alternately charged and discharged:

![schematic](https://i.stack.imgur.com/lq83i.png)

[simulate this circuit](/plugins/schematics?image=http%3a%2f%2fi.stack.imgur.com%2flq83i.png)

Assume, as before, that the ground symbol may be understood as earthing or the use of any reference convenient to you.

Initially, SW1 and SW3 are closed, causing the potential at A to rise above the potential at B. Then, SW1 and SW3 are opened, and then SW2 and SW4 are closed. Since A is below B, but A is now connected to ground (be it earth ground, your Arduino's GND connection, Mars ground, etc), hence B and VOUT are both below earth ground. With the addition of extra capacitors, and the use of fast semiconductor switches, this is something that is [commercially realized](http://www.analog.com/media/en/technical-documentation/data-sheets/3261fb.pdf) as a practical way to produce voltages lower than your lowest supply.

With the appropriate safety precautions and appropriate components and measurement tools, you should be able to verify both of these examples and claims for yourself if you so desire.

1.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A circuit designer needs to create a -5V supply for a sensitive analog circuit in a system where the main power supply only provides +12V and GND. Which of the following methods would be most appropriate to generate the required -5V, assuming the circuit requires a true negative voltage with respect to earth ground?

A) Use a voltage divider to create +5V and use it as a new reference ground
B) Implement a charge pump circuit with appropriate switching elements
C) Connect the negative terminal of the +12V supply to earth ground
D) Use two series-connected 6V Zener diodes in reverse

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A) This method would create a virtual ground at +5V, but wouldn't produce a true negative voltage relative to earth ground.
B) A charge pump circuit can generate a true negative voltage from a positive supply, making it suitable for creating -5V from +12V.
C) This would short circuit the power supply and potentially cause damage.
D) Zener diodes in reverse would regulate voltage, but cannot generate a negative voltage from a positive supply.

The charge pump (option B) is the most appropriate solution as it can produce a genuine negative voltage referenced to earth ground, as explained in the documentation. It uses switches and capacitors to effectively "pump" charge to create a voltage lower than the ground reference.

\#\#\# Top Answer: Restoring cmd, bat and exe associations work differently from other file types.

To restore these, run CMD.EXE as Administrator, then:

```
Microsoft Windows [Version 6.0.6003]
Copyright (c) 2006 Microsoft Corporation.  All rights reserved.

C:\Windows\system32>assoc .bat=exefile
.bat=exefile

C:\Windows\system32>assoc .cmd=exefile
.cmd=exefile

```

That's it!

3.answer:
Based on the provided documentation, here's a multi-form question for an exam:

Question: When restoring file associations for cmd, bat, and exe files in Windows, which of the following statements is correct?

A) These file associations can be restored using the same method as other file types in Windows.
B) To restore these associations, you must edit the Windows registry directly.
C) The command to restore .bat and .cmd associations is "assoc .bat=batfile" and "assoc .cmd=cmdfile" respectively.
D) You need to run CMD.EXE as Administrator and use the "assoc" command to associate .bat and .cmd with "exefile".

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct method to restore cmd, bat, and exe file associations in Windows is different from other file types. You need to run the Command Prompt (CMD.EXE) as an Administrator, then use the "assoc" command to associate .bat and .cmd files with "exefile". The correct commands are "assoc .bat=exefile" and "assoc .cmd=exefile". This method ensures that these system-critical file types are properly associated and can be executed correctly by the operating system.

`file1`

```
M,M
A,M
A,A
M,A

```

Expected output:

If the first columns in the first row is the same, I want to print the second column in the output file, i.e.

```
M (for first line)
0 (for second line not same, zero value)
A (for third line)
0 (for fourth line not same, zero value)

```

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
```
awk -F , '{ if ($1 == $2) print $2; else print 0; }' inputfile

```

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: You have a CSV file with two columns and want to compare them, printing the second column value if they match or 0 if they don't. Which awk command correctly accomplishes this task?

A) awk -F , '{ if ($1 = $2) print $2; else print 0; }' inputfile

B) awk -F , '{ if ($1 == $2) print $2; else print 0; }' inputfile

C) awk -F , '{ if ($1 eq $2) print $2; else print 0; }' inputfile

D) awk -F , '{ if ($1 === $2) print $2; else print 0; }' inputfile

Correct Answer: B

Explanations:

A) This option uses a single equals sign (=), which is an assignment operator in awk, not a comparison operator. It would always evaluate to true, leading to incorrect results.

B) This is the correct option. It uses the proper comparison operator (==) for equality in awk, and correctly prints the second column if the columns match, or 0 if they don't.

C) This option uses 'eq' for comparison, which is not a valid operator in awk. Awk uses '==' for string equality comparisons.

D) This option uses the triple equals sign (===), which is not a valid operator in awk. It's commonly used in languages like JavaScript, but not in awk.

\#\#\# User: I came across this question in my textbook:

> The first stage of a 2\-stage amplifier has a voltage gain of \\$150\\$,
>  an input resistance of \\$1500 \\Omega\\$, an equivalent noise resistance
>  of \\$700 \\Omega\\$ and an output resistance of \\$20 k\\Omega\\$. For the
>  second stage, these values are \\$500\\$, \\$50 k\\Omega\\$, \\$1200
>  \\Omega\\$, and \\$1 M\\Omega\\$ respectively. 
> 
> 
> 1. Sketch the circuit diagram illustrating this scenario
> 2. Calculate the equivalent noise resistance of this 2\-stage amplifier

I'm having a bit of a confusion regarding this question. **Shouldn't the output resistance of the first stage be same as the input resistance of the second stage of the amplifier i.e. \\$R\_2\\$?** 

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/IvxOf.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/IvxOf.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The impedances need to match for maximum power transfer, but you probably don't care so much about that for the first stage output. But the input impedance of the second stage should probably be higher than the output impedance of the first stage, or the second stage will load the first stage and limit your operating range.

An ideal amplifier has infinite input impedance and zero output impedance, or at least a reasonable facsimile of those conditions. On the other hand, if your first stage tries to drive 10V through an output impedance is 1k and into an input impedance of 10 ohms, then the second stage will receive $$\\frac{10V\\cdot10}{(1k\+10\)ohms} \= 0\.1V.$$ 

In your case, you're driving through 20k into 50k. So your second stage will see $$\\frac{50}{(50\+20\)}$$ or 5/7 of whatever the first stage puts out.

Sorry I don't know Mathjax so ugly equations. BTW, what is this textbook you're using?

5.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A two-stage amplifier has the following characteristics:
Stage 1: Voltage gain = 150, Input resistance = 1500 Ω, Output resistance = 20 kΩ
Stage 2: Voltage gain = 500, Input resistance = 50 kΩ, Output resistance = 1 MΩ

If the first stage produces an output voltage of 3V, what will be the approximate voltage seen at the input of the second stage?

A) 2.14V
B) 2.50V
C) 2.86V
D) 3.00V

Correct Answer: A) 2.14V

Explanation: The voltage seen at the input of the second stage will be less than the output voltage of the first stage due to the voltage division between the output resistance of the first stage and the input resistance of the second stage. We can calculate this using the voltage divider formula:

V_in(stage2) = V_out(stage1) * (R_in(stage2) / (R_out(stage1) + R_in(stage2)))

V_in(stage2) = 3V * (50kΩ / (20kΩ + 50kΩ))
             = 3V * (50 / 70)
             = 3V * (5/7)
             ≈ 2.14V

This question tests understanding of impedance matching between amplifier stages and the concept of voltage division. Options B, C, and D represent common misconceptions or errors in calculation.

\#\#\# Top Answer: If the can (with no top) was tilted and the beads fell out, that is not "bursting".  

*bursting* would be (for example) when a sealed container with some contents builds up pressure inside the container, so that it would break open. 

I would say:

> The beads **spilled** all over the floor.

[*spill*](https://ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=spill):

> 1. To cause or allow (a substance) to run or fall out of a container.
> 2. To scatter (objects) from containment: *spilled the armload of books on the desk*.

6.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Which verb best describes the action of beads falling out of a tilted, open container onto the floor?

A) Burst
B) Spill
C) Explode
D) Erupt

Correct Answer: B

Explanations:

A) Burst is incorrect. Bursting typically refers to a sealed container breaking open due to internal pressure, which is not the case here.

B) Spill is correct. To spill means to cause or allow a substance to run or fall out of a container, which accurately describes beads falling out of a tilted, open container.

C) Explode is incorrect. Explosion involves a sudden and violent release of energy, which doesn't apply to beads simply falling out of a container.

D) Erupt is incorrect. Eruption usually refers to a sudden, forceful ejection, often associated with volcanoes or geysers, which is not appropriate for describing beads falling out of a container.

\#\#\# User: I would like to search within an individual email message using OS X Mail version 5\.3 or above (Lion, Mountain Lion). I would like this search to include the email header.

Using the menu item `Edit > Find > Find…` or `Command-F` via the keyboard I am able to search the entire message, exclusive of the header. I would like to search the header, also.

An example of how this would be used: An email message is sent to hundreds of recipients which you want to search to find a specific email address.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: After months of assuming there was no solution to my inquiry, I stumbled on a way to search the *entire* contents of an individual OS X Mail Message, **including headers.**

First open the email message you want to search **in it's own window.** *Before* initiating your search, select the menu item `View > Message > Raw Source` or alternately `Option-Command-U` from the keyboard. This will bring forward a new menu with the entire plain\-text content of your message, including extraneous information such as headers.

If you search this *Raw Source* version of your message using `Command-F` or `Edit > Find > Find…` from the menu, the search will include *everything* in the message, including the headers.

> Note: Although I'm currently using OS X Mail version 6\.5, I verified that this technique also works at least back to version 5\.3\.

9.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are using OS X Mail version 6.0 and need to search for a specific email address within the header of a message sent to hundreds of recipients. Which sequence of steps would allow you to perform this search?

A) Open the email message, press Command-F, and enter the email address in the search bar.

B) Open the email message in its own window, select View > Message > Raw Source, then use Command-F to search.

C) Open the email message, select Edit > Find > Find..., and enter the email address in the search bar.

D) Right-click on the email message, select "Show Original", then use the browser's search function to find the email address.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because using Command-F alone will only search the body of the email, not including the header.

Option B is the correct answer. By opening the email in its own window and selecting View > Message > Raw Source (or using Option-Command-U), you can view the entire plain-text content of the message, including headers. Then, using Command-F will allow you to search this raw source, which includes the header information.

Option C is incorrect for the same reason as A - it only searches the body of the email, not the header.

Option D is incorrect because "Show Original" is not a standard option in OS X Mail. While this method might work in some other email clients, it's not applicable to the scenario described using OS X Mail.

The correct method allows for searching within the header, which is necessary when looking for a specific email address among many recipients.

\#\#\# User: Is there any difference between "processor" and "processer"?

Some spelling dictionaries only have the \-or form, and some have both. Is it a US vs UK English thing? Or something else?

More specifically, is a computer algorithm that processes orders better called an `OrderProcessor` or an `OrderProcesser`?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Use `processor`. While `processer` is in the OED, its [overall usage](https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=processor,processer&year_start=1920&year_end=2000&corpus=15&smoothing=3&share=&direct_url=t1;,processor;,c0;.t1;,processer;,c0) is so low that people are likely to see it as an error. As written in [this answer](https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/4733/whats-the-rule-for-adding-er-vs-or-when-nouning-a-verb/4734#4734), most English agent words user the "\-er" suffix, except for those based on Latin words which follow the Latin rules. "Process" ultimately comes from Latin via French.

![A Google ngram chart showing processor ending in o r with high usage and processer ending in e r with practically no indication of usage.](https://i.stack.imgur.com/KLTcE.png)

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In software engineering, when naming a class that handles order processing, which of the following is the most appropriate and widely accepted naming convention?

A) OrderProcesser
B) OrderProcessor
C) OrderHandler
D) OrderManager

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B) OrderProcessor. This follows the widely accepted naming convention for agent nouns derived from Latin-based words like "process." While both "processor" and "processer" exist in some dictionaries, "processor" is significantly more common and less likely to be perceived as an error.

Option A is incorrect because "processer," though listed in some dictionaries, has extremely low usage and may be seen as a spelling mistake by many readers.

Options C and D, while not incorrect in terms of spelling or grammar, do not directly address the specific term discussed in the original question. They are alternative naming conventions that don't capture the precise functionality of processing as accurately as "processor."

This question tests the student's understanding of naming conventions in programming, their awareness of linguistic nuances in technical terminology, and their ability to choose the most widely accepted and professionally appropriate option.

\#\#\# User: Could you give an example of an equiareal map that is not a local isometry? 

$$$$ 

---

$$$$ 

A local diffeomorphism $f : S\_1 \\rightarrow S\_2$ is equiareal if and only if, for any surface patch $\\sigma (u, v)$ on $S\_1$, the first fundamental forms $$E\_1du^2 \+ 2F\_1dudv \+ G\_1dv^2 \\ \\text{ and } \\ E\_2du^2 \+ 2F\_2dudv \+ G\_2dv^2$$ of the patches $\\sigma$ on $S\_1$ and $f \\circ \\sigma$ on $S\_2$ satisfy $$E\_1G\_1− F^2\_1 \= E\_2G\_2 − F^2\_2$$ 

$$$$ 

---

$$$$ 

A local diffeomorphism $f : S\_1 \\rightarrow S\_2$ is a local isometry if and only if, for any surface patch $\\sigma\_1$ of $S\_1$, the patches $\\sigma\_1$ and $f \\circ \\sigma\_1$ of $S\_1$ and $S\_2$, respectively, have the same first fundamental form.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: $$ (x,y) \\mapsto (x\+y,y) $$ in the ordinary plane

16.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Consider the map f: ℝ² → ℝ² defined by f(x,y) = (x+y, y). Which of the following statements is true about this map?

A) It is both equiareal and a local isometry.
B) It is equiareal but not a local isometry.
C) It is a local isometry but not equiareal.
D) It is neither equiareal nor a local isometry.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

This map f(x,y) = (x+y, y) is indeed equiareal but not a local isometry.

To see that it's equiareal, we can compute the Jacobian determinant:
∂(x+y)/∂x = 1, ∂(x+y)/∂y = 1
∂y/∂x = 0, ∂y/∂y = 1
Det J = 1(1) - 1(0) = 1

Since the Jacobian determinant is 1 everywhere, the map preserves areas and is thus equiareal.

However, it's not a local isometry because it doesn't preserve distances. For example, consider the vector (1,0). Under this map, it becomes (1,0), which has the same length. But the vector (0,1) becomes (1,1), which is longer than the original vector.

In terms of the first fundamental form, for the original plane we have E₁ = G₁ = 1, F₁ = 0. For the image under f, we get E₂ = 2, G₂ = 1, F₂ = 1. These are not the same, so f is not a local isometry.

This example demonstrates that a map can preserve areas without preserving distances or angles, making it an equiareal map that is not a local isometry.

\#\#\# User: I have a large quantity of game data that I am trying to perform prediction with. The goal is to identify whether certain card groupings have advantages when played against opposing hands. As part of my approach (because there are large combinations of selected cards), it is useful to perform segmentation into common groupings.

My question relates to the symmetry of information since both the "home" and "away" player are gravitating to common card segment groupings. Here is an illustration of the dataset:

```
Home_segment     Away_segment     Outcome
2                4                0
3                1                1
7                1                0
4                2                1
1                3                0
...
n rows
...
3                6                1
1                7                0

```

As constructed, you'll note that segment 4 appears to have an advantage over segment 2, and if the pattern continued through the data, this would be a useful insight.

My question, however, is that in creating a predictor using "home" and "away" in this format, the information contained by the "reverse perspectives" appears to be discarded. That is, when segment 4 becomes the home segment, and 2 is the away segment, it seems to me that the prior relationship is not considered in the modelling solution.

Should I effective "double" my dataset by reversing the home / away positions? Do I introduce independence issues by doing so? Interested in perspectives and how I can most effectively model using a dataset with this construct.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The first thing to note is that the logistic regression model you describe in your comments has *more* parameters ($n^2 \+ 2n$) than there are segment combinations ($n^2$), meaning that it is *overparametrized* and therefore will just give you the observed frequency of wins for each possible combination.

If that is what you are interested in, you don't really need to perform logistic regression \- simply count the number of wins for each combination and treat it as a standard binomial estimation problem (with $k$ wins for a given segment out of $m$ games). This way you can deal with symmetry by considering reversed positions as the same combination \- just count for example (4,2\) and (2,4\) together, so you have in total $n(n\+1\)/2$ combinations instead of $n^2$, and you get a estimated win probability for each.

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the StackExchange documentation:

Question: In a card game prediction model where home and away segments are analyzed, what is the most appropriate method to handle the symmetry of information and avoid overparameterization?

A) Double the dataset by reversing home and away positions for each entry
B) Use logistic regression with n^2 + 2n parameters, where n is the number of segments
C) Treat reversed positions as the same combination and use binomial estimation for n(n+1)/2 combinations
D) Create separate models for home and away segments to capture unique advantages

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most appropriate method because it addresses the symmetry issue by considering reversed positions (e.g., 4,2 and 2,4) as the same combination. This approach reduces the number of combinations from n^2 to n(n+1)/2, avoiding overparameterization. It also allows for standard binomial estimation of win probabilities for each unique combination, providing a more efficient and statistically sound method for analyzing the data. Options A and B would lead to overparameterization or redundancy, while option D doesn't address the symmetry issue and may not capture the relationships between segment combinations effectively.

\#\#\# Top Answer: The instructions on this page worked for me (Ubuntu 18\.04, GTX 1650s): <https://github.com/lutris/docs/blob/master/InstallingDrivers.md>

Nvidia:

To get the latest Nvidia drivers it is necessary to add the Proprietary GPU Drivers PPA:

`sudo add-apt-repository ppa:graphics-drivers/ppa`

Enable 32 bit architecture (if you haven't already):

`sudo dpkg --add-architecture i386`

Update to refresh packages:

`sudo apt update`

Warning: Please ensure your graphics card is supported by the 430 driver before installing. For a list of supported GPUs click here: [https://www.nvidia.com/Download/driverResults.aspx/149138/en\-us](https://www.nvidia.com/Download/driverResults.aspx/149138/en-us)

Install the 440\.82 driver:

`sudo apt install nvidia-driver-440 libnvidia-gl-440 libnvidia-gl-440:i386`

Install support for Vulkan API (will be functional only if you have a Vulkan capable GPU):

`sudo apt install libvulkan1 libvulkan1:i386`

**Reboot to apply changes.**

\#\#\# User: [![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/LiVAq.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/LiVAq.png)This question is generated by the curiosity of mind while solving a numerical from a book of mechanics.  

As the force of gravity is a vector quantity, it acts from center of mass which implies that it will act from center to center of an object.  

I was thinking of a small object (isotropic, spherical, uniform) that gets stuck between two heavy spherical masses having the same geometry and property, and all three of them with no initial velocity in space.  

Picture for demonstration attached.  

My questions are `"Where will the small mass move?`  

`Is it toward Mass 1 or Mass 2? Or it will remain stuck forever?`  

`Is Gravity continuous, that holds the object in equilibrium state?`  

`Will the small object act as a medium to attract both masses that will make them revolve around the smaller one?`

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you are working in Newtonian gravity (I assume you are, seeing the tag) and therefore you neglect all relativistic/quantum effects, then **the central mass will stay in the same spot** if placed exactly in the center of mass of the system.

The two bigger masses will be attracted towards the center by the small mass and the other big mass (and nothing stops them) while the small mass will be pulled in two opposite directions with the same magnitude, therefore (since the gravitational force, same as any force, is a vector) the two will cancel out.  

For the conservation of angular momentum, if the system isn't rotating at the beginning it will continue to not rotate, and the movement will be completely linear along the axis passing through the center of the bodies.  

As for the "is gravity continuous", it certainly is in Newtonian gravity, as well as in General Relativity (the best we can nowadays do to explain gravity). However, the question in a Quantum\-Gravity environment is far from obvious: we just don't know.

Bonus: you can generalize this question with different, moving masses. It's the [Lagrange points](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_point) problem and the point you're asking about is [L1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_point#L1) that can be found (numerically in general, analytically with some assumptions).

20.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In a theoretical scenario involving three spherical masses in space with no initial velocity, a small object M is placed exactly between two larger identical masses M1 and M2. Assuming Newtonian gravity and neglecting all relativistic/quantum effects, what would be the behavior of the small object M?

A) M will move towards M1 due to slight gravitational imbalances
B) M will oscillate back and forth between M1 and M2
C) M will remain stationary at its initial position
D) M will cause M1 and M2 to orbit around it

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to Newtonian gravity, the small object M will remain stationary at its initial position. This is because it is placed at the center of mass of the system, experiencing equal gravitational pulls from both M1 and M2 in opposite directions. These forces cancel each other out, resulting in no net force on M. The larger masses M1 and M2 will be attracted towards the center by both the small mass M and each other, but M itself will not move if it's exactly centered. This scenario is analogous to the Lagrange point L1 in celestial mechanics. The system's angular momentum is conserved, and since it starts with no rotation, it will continue without rotation, with any movement being linear along the axis passing through the centers of the bodies.

UPDATE: I just did a lockscreen, and got an image that IS in that directory, but earlier today, it was consistently an image of an interesting footbridge that is **not** in that directory.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you are not finding the images in the typical locations, you likely have `Windows Spotlight` turned on. Spotlight offers random images on the lock screen, as well as other features. 

> These Windows Spotlight images aren’t stored in the same location as
>  regular Windows wallpaper, however, so here’s how you can find them.

The images are **hidden** deep, so you will need to change settings before you can view them. To do this, open File Explorer and go to the `View` tab. On the far right is an `Options` button, click it. 

In the window that opens, select the `View` tab. Under `Advanced Settings`, select `Show hidden files, folders and drives`, then click `Apply` and then `OK` to close the open window.

Now it is time to navigate to the following directory (which was hidden before).

**`This PC > C: > Users > [Your User Name] > AppData > Local > Packages > Microsoft.Windows.ContentDeliveryManager_cw5n1h2txyewy > LocalState > Assets`**

In this directory you will see a bunch of files without extensions. These are the incognito image files. These are `jpeg` images of various resolutions to meet the needs of multiple devices screen sizes. You can copy the files to another location and rename them to have the `jpeg` extension, then you can open them with your default image viewer. 

[source](https://www.tekrevue.com/tip/find-windows-spotlight-lock-screen-images-windows-10/)

22.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You want to locate and access the rotating lock screen images on your Windows 10 computer, but can't find them in the usual wallpaper locations. What series of steps would you need to take to view these images?

A) Navigate to C:\Windows\System32\oobe\info\backgrounds and copy the image files to a new location.

B) Enable "Show hidden files, folders, and drives" in File Explorer options, then navigate to C:\Users\[Your User Name]\AppData\Local\Packages\Microsoft.Windows.ContentDeliveryManager_cw5n1h2txyewy\LocalState\Assets, copy the files, and rename them with a .jpeg extension.

C) Open the Registry Editor, navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Authentication\LogonUI\Background, and export the binary data of the "OEMBackground" value.

D) Use a third-party software to scan and extract all image files from the Windows.edb database located in C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\SearchIndex.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct procedure to access the Windows Spotlight lock screen images involves first enabling hidden files and folders in File Explorer options. Then, you need to navigate to the specific hidden folder: C:\Users\[Your User Name]\AppData\Local\Packages\Microsoft.Windows.ContentDeliveryManager_cw5n1h2txyewy\LocalState\Assets. In this folder, you'll find files without extensions, which are actually JPEG images. To view them, you need to copy these files to another location and add the .jpeg extension. This process aligns with the information provided in the documentation about accessing Windows Spotlight images, which are stored differently from regular wallpapers.

\#\#\# Top Answer: Don’t worry about it, nothing will happen.

In the off chance that something *does* go wrong, you’ll always be able to reset the iPod to factory settings and start over with a fresh iOS 5 install.

It’s virtually impossible to break an iPod just by upgrading it the recommended way.

\#\#\# User: How can I successfully update [catalog Inventory Stock for a particular Item](http://www.magentocommerce.com/api/soap/catalogInventory/cataloginventory_stock_item.update.html)?

According to the API, this should be as simple as populating the properties and then making the call.

```
Dim objWS As MagentoService
Dim inventoryResult As Integer = objWS.catalogInventoryStockItemUpdate(
    sSessionId,
    sku,
    New catalogInventoryStockItemUpdateEntity With 
        {.manage_stock = 1, .is_in_stock = 1, .qty = 1})

```

However investigating with fiddler reveals that the message sent over the wire doesn't contain all the information, but only the quantity like below.

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
    <soap:Body>
        <catalogInventoryStockItemUpdateRequestParam xmlns="urn:Magento">
            <sessionId xmlns="">62eee280a948d48b2f5c57efd4b5548f</sessionId>
            <productId xmlns="">4000</productId>
            <data xmlns="">
                <qty>1</qty>
            </data>
        </catalogInventoryStockItemUpdateRequestParam>
    </soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>

```

Am I doing something wrong, Or is this a bug with Magento? There is a [similar unanswered question on their official forums](http://www.magentocommerce.com/boards/viewthread/290515/).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Fortunately, the question on the form was [answered](http://www.magentocommerce.com/boards/viewthread/290515/#t465298). However I had a different issue. In the Magento API, you need to set the value and then tell it that you set the value.

Here's an example below:

```
Dim objWS As MagentoService
Dim inventoryResult As Integer = objWS.catalogInventoryStockItemUpdate(
    sSessionId,
    sku,
    New catalogInventoryStockItemUpdateEntity With 
        {
            .manage_stock = 1,              
            .manage_stockSpecified = True, 
            .is_in_stock = 1, 
            .is_in_StockSpecified = True, 
            .qty = 1
        })

```

25.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: When updating catalog inventory stock for a particular item in Magento using the SOAP API, which of the following code snippets correctly sets both the quantity and the "manage stock" flag?

A) 
```
New catalogInventoryStockItemUpdateEntity With 
{
    .manage_stock = 1, 
    .qty = 1
}
```

B) 
```
New catalogInventoryStockItemUpdateEntity With 
{
    .manage_stock = 1, 
    .manage_stockSpecified = True, 
    .qty = 1
}
```

C) 
```
New catalogInventoryStockItemUpdateEntity With 
{
    .manage_stock = 1, 
    .is_in_stock = 1, 
    .qty = 1
}
```

D) 
```
New catalogInventoryStockItemUpdateEntity With 
{
    .manage_stock = 1, 
    .manage_stockSpecified = True, 
    .is_in_stock = 1,
    .is_in_stockSpecified = True, 
    .qty = 1
}
```

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: In the Magento API, when updating inventory stock, you need to not only set the value but also explicitly specify that you've set the value. Option B correctly sets the `manage_stock` flag to 1 and also sets `manage_stockSpecified` to True, which tells the API that this value has been intentionally set. Option A doesn't specify that `manage_stock` has been set, C doesn't use the required "Specified" flags, and D includes unnecessary `is_in_stock` settings.

\#\#\# User: I have to perform correlation test between repeated and not repeated measures, more accurately e.g.: I sampled 20 individuals in 10 populations and I measured some traits (e.g. height) on the individuals and I have climatic variables (e.g. temperature) for each population. Now I want to compute correlation e.g. between height (10\*20 values) and temperature (10\*1 value).

Here is my question : is it better to take the mean values of measured traits for each population or to "repeat" the climatic variable for each individual ? (and why ?) 

Does anyone know a better way to deal with this issue ?

I hope this is understandable and thank in advance for your help.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I've never seen any constraint on the number of epochs, but I think it doesn't make much sense... You can try setting a desired training error **e** and a maximum number of epochs **n**. If **n** is reached before **e** is achieved, stop the training and start testing, and the lowest error will be reported as the training error of the model. You train with 9 folders, and test with the other one.

I think you might be confused about training and test error. Training error is achieved iteratively, the parameters are changing; testing error is achieved with fixed parameters, there is no epoch number for testing error.

Nevertheless, ***always*** make it clear how you're doing the training/testing!

27.answer:
Question: A researcher is studying the relationship between individual plant heights and average temperature across multiple populations. They have collected data on 20 plants from each of 10 different populations, along with the average temperature for each population. Which of the following approaches would be most appropriate for analyzing the correlation between plant height and temperature, and why?

A) Calculate the mean plant height for each population and correlate these 10 values with the 10 temperature measurements.

B) Repeat the temperature value for each population 20 times (once for each plant) and correlate all 200 plant heights with the 200 repeated temperature values.

C) Use a mixed-effects model with temperature as a fixed effect and population as a random effect.

D) Randomly select one plant from each population and correlate these 10 heights with the 10 temperature measurements.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the most appropriate approach for this analysis. Here's why:

A) While this approach reduces the data to the population level, it loses information about individual variation within populations and reduces statistical power.

B) This method artificially inflates the sample size and violates the assumption of independence, potentially leading to spurious correlations.

C) A mixed-effects model is ideal for this scenario as it accounts for the hierarchical structure of the data (plants nested within populations) while allowing for the analysis of both individual- and population-level effects. It can handle the repeated measures within populations and the single temperature measurement per population.

D) This approach wastes a lot of data and introduces unnecessary randomness into the analysis.

The mixed-effects model (C) is the best choice because it preserves all the data, accounts for the data structure, and allows for proper inference about the relationship between plant height and temperature while controlling for population-level effects.

pam_access is disabled ()

\#\#\# Top Answer: Solved!

I happened to notice this line in `/var/log/messages` on my NFS server when I was attempting to mount an export from the remote client:

```
Feb 28 15:54:02 storage1 rpc.idmapd[1651]: nss_getpwnam: name 'nobody' does not map into domain 'localdomain'

```

This caused me to look at the first few lines of `/etc/idmapd.conf`: 

```
[General]
#Verbosity = 0
# The following should be set to the local NFSv4 domain name
# The default is the host's DNS domain name.
#Domain = local.domain.edu

```

I then added `Domain=subdomain.mycompany.com` under the commented out "Domain" line. Saved, exited and then ran `/etc/init.d/rpcidmapd restart` and `/etc/init.d/nfs restart`.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A system administrator is troubleshooting an issue where files in NFS-mounted directories appear to be owned by nobody:nobody (uid: 99, gid: 99) on the client machine, despite the user having the correct uid and gid. After investigation, the administrator notices an error in the server's /var/log/messages related to rpc.idmapd. What is the most likely solution to this problem?

A) Modify the /etc/fstab file on the client to include the 'nfsvers=4' option for the NFS mounts
B) Update the LDAP configuration in /etc/sssd/sssd.conf to include the correct domain information
C) Add or modify the 'Domain' setting in /etc/idmapd.conf on the NFS server to match the local NFSv4 domain name
D) Change the 'auth_provider' in /etc/sssd/sssd.conf from 'ldap' to 'local' to prioritize local user information

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct solution is to modify the /etc/idmapd.conf file on the NFS server. The error message in /var/log/messages indicates that the 'nobody' user is not mapping correctly into the domain. By adding or modifying the 'Domain' setting in /etc/idmapd.conf to match the local NFSv4 domain name (e.g., Domain=subdomain.mycompany.com), the server can properly map user and group IDs between the client and server. After making this change, restarting the rpcidmapd and nfs services should resolve the issue of files appearing to be owned by nobody:nobody.

\#\#\# User: I have found an open source library that can work fine with my project,
but I have noted that It's not frequently updated and I'm afraid of not having the necessary support.

Is the frequency of updates a proper criterion for choosing an open source library rather than another?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It can be, if you expect that the code you're reusing will often have defects that will cause defects in your application, and therefore have to be fixed. (Of course, you should thoroughly test the part of the library that you actually used and verify that it does the job correctly *before* you ship it with your product, but we all know the world isn't that tidy.) If this is the case you should not make commercial success dependent on third\-party libraries where you are not sure about support \- whether open\-source or not! 

But bear in mind that "few updates" and "likely to have defects" is not necessarily correlated. In fact, it may be anti\-correlated for very wide\-spread, very mature products. And of course, the bonus of open source is that if there *is* a defect with a clear and obvious fix, you can just make the fix without having to wait for external support at all.

29.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A software developer is considering using an open-source library for a critical component of their commercial product. The library seems to fit their needs perfectly, but it hasn't been updated in over a year. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate course of action for the developer?

A) Immediately discard the library option and look for alternatives with more frequent updates.
B) Use the library without hesitation, as lack of updates indicates stability and maturity.
C) Thoroughly test the relevant parts of the library, assess its current suitability, and consider the team's ability to maintain it if necessary.
D) Contact the library's maintainers and offer to pay for regular updates before using it.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the most appropriate course of action because:

1. Thorough testing of the relevant parts ensures the library meets the current needs of the project.
2. Assessing current suitability aligns with the advice to verify that the library "does the job correctly before you ship it with your product."
3. Considering the team's ability to maintain the library acknowledges the benefit of open-source software, where "if there is a defect with a clear and obvious fix, you can just make the fix without having to wait for external support."

Option A is incorrect because frequency of updates isn't necessarily correlated with quality or suitability. The documentation states that "few updates" and "likely to have defects" are not necessarily correlated.

Option B is incorrect because while lack of updates could indicate stability, it's not a guarantee. The developer should still thoroughly test and assess the library.

Option D is incorrect because it's an unnecessary step if the library is already suitable and stable. The documentation doesn't suggest paying for updates as a primary solution.

\#\#\# User: What is the correct use of pronoun with each/every/each of

* Each of the boys *has/have* brought *his/their* pen.
* Each boy *has/have* brought *his/their* pen.

Please explain which is correct pronoun here, **his or their**

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I would say in this particular example where we're talking about `boys`, in both cases,

> `each` is singular and therefore `has`/`his` is correct

However, today, in situations where (1\) gender is unknown, (2\) the group comprise both genders, or (3\) there are gender\-fluid individuals in the group, it has become more normal to adopt the *gender\-neutral* `their` (and correspondingly `have`) instead of `his`. 

> Each student should hand in **their** homework on time.
> 
> 
> Each and every employee is expected to submit **their** punch card.

Assuming the male gender as representative of everyone can at best be deemed an outdated notion from a bygone era, and at worst insensitive and offensive. Of course, we could say `his or her` but that sounds a little clumsy compared to `their`.

That said, in the original example, if it's fairly certain that the 'boys' do not have anyone who is gender\-fluid in the group, we really should stick to `has/his`.

30.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a gender-diverse classroom, which of the following sentences is most appropriate and inclusive when addressing all students?

A) Each student must submit his assignment by Friday.
B) Every pupil should bring their textbook to class.
C) Each of the students has to present his or her project next week.
D) Every learner have to complete their exam within the time limit.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
Option B is the most appropriate and inclusive choice for a gender-diverse classroom. Here's why:

A) This uses "his," which assumes all students are male and is not inclusive.
B) This uses "their" as a gender-neutral singular pronoun, which is inclusive of all gender identities. It also correctly uses "should bring" with "Every pupil."
C) While this attempts to be inclusive by using "his or her," it can be cumbersome and still excludes non-binary individuals.
D) This option uses the inclusive "their," but it contains a grammatical error: "have" should be "has" to agree with the singular "Every learner."

Option B demonstrates the modern, inclusive use of "their" as a singular pronoun while maintaining grammatical correctness, making it the best choice for a diverse classroom setting.

\#\#\# User: My textbook states that an ordered set S has the least upper bound property if the following is true:  

If $E \\subset S, E $ is not empty and is bounded above, then $sup E$ exists in S.  

But consider the set of rational numbers $\\mathbb Q$, and a subset $S \= {{1,2,3}}$. $S$ is not empty. It's also bounded above. $sup S\=3$ also exists in $\\mathbb Q$. But the set of rational numbers does not have a supremum!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: My answer will have to be "yes and no".

In the formal sense, the answer is no. $\\ell^p$ consists of elements of the form $a: \\mathbb N \\longrightarrow \\mathbb C$. However, such a finite sequence is something of the form $a: \\{1, \\dots, N\\} \\longrightarrow \\mathbb C$. This is not a function with domain $\\mathbb N$ so strictly speaking it is not in $\\ell^p$.

However, I think this question relates to a deeper concept than mere formalism \- it's about how math is communicated. We are not always so strict in math. Surely, speaking strictly is useful. We must be precise when doing math, as subtle errors abound, especially when one is encountering a new topic. However, we often abuse notation and speak more loosely when we are working practically, as strictness can become cumbersome. Ultimately, math is a communicative process. What you write down is meant to be understood by another person doing math. If I read "$\\{a\_n\\}\_{n\=1}^N \\in \\ell^p$" it would be immediately clear to me that what you meant is the extension by $0$ you describe. This is a routine thing to do, and contextually the meaning is clear. It may even be annoying for a reader if you were to belabor this point, but this depends on your audience. As with any form of speech, the particular language mathematicians use has imprecisions that are filled in by contextual understanding. It's the duty of a good author to determine what things their audience can pick up from context and what things must be spelled out.

Let me give another example. Is $\\mathbb R \\subseteq \\mathbb C$? Well sure, we say this all the time. But often we consider $\\mathbb C$ to be the set $\\mathbb R^2$ with additional structure. Elements of $\\mathbb R^2$ are pairs of real numbers, and a real number is not a pair of real numbers, so if we again insist on speaking strictly, then it's not true that $\\mathbb R \\subseteq \\mathbb C$. But this is pedantry. We do freely think about the real numbers as sitting in the complex numbers without caring that on a technical set theoretic level it may not be strictly true. On that note, objects are not always even well defined. Are complex numbers pairs of real numbers? Cosets in $\\mathbb R\[x]/(x^2 \+ 1\)$? Are real numbers equivalence classes of Cauchy sequences? Dedekind cuts? None of these sets contain one another, but does it really matter? When I say $\\mathbb R \\subseteq \\mathbb C$ or $\\{a\_n\\}\_{n\=1}^N \\in \\ell^p$, I expect my audience to be able to infer the meaning of these statements without my having to spell out all the little details. Doing so would be tedious for both me as an author, and for the reader to actually read.

I'll leave you with some rough guidelines, but I myself am a novice in mathematical writing. I'd encourage you to seek out experts who have written about this, such as [Terry Tao on his blog](https://terrytao.wordpress.com/advice-on-writing-papers/) (EDIT: [This](https://terrytao.wordpress.com/advice-on-writing-papers/on-compilation-errors-in-mathematical-reading-and-how-to-resolve-them/) particular post on "compilation errors" is especially relevant) or any personal mentors you have. Additionally, having peers and members of your intended audience comment on what you've written is deeply important.

First and foremost, especially as a beginner, is to be correct and precise. You must be completely sure that everything you write down is correct, and that any skipped details are things you can readily fill in if asked. If you write down $\\mathbb R \\subseteq \\mathbb C$ or $\\{a\_n\\}\_{n\=1}^N \\in \\ell^p$, be prepared to defend it!

Secondly, think about who your audience is. Are you writing homework for a class? Perhaps then the grader will want to see every detail spelled out to determine if you are indeed capable of doing so. Are you preparing lecture notes for people learning analysis for the first time? Maybe this abuse of notation would confuse them. For advanced graduate students? They're probably used to things like this. Are these notes just for you? Are they for a textbook? Each audience and medium will have different expectations and standards. You should consider what your audience is likely to know, how much time they have to sit and digest the material itself, and what constraints the medium imposes \- like if you have only an hour for a talk.

\#\#\# User: What are the benefits of using a chatroom instead of asking a question directly on a Stack Exchange site? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: * Sometimes, a question can be too broad or too opinion\-based for the Stack Exchange Q\&A sites. A simple example would be "I'm a Java developer, how do I get started with Python?" I'm not familiar with the culture of the Python chatroom on Stack Overflow, but they might be willing to help.
* If you have trouble phrasing your question correctly, or generating a ~~MCVE~~ [reprex](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example), users in a chatroom might be able to help you interactively, in a better way than comments and/or downvotes on a poor question do.
	+ Please don't forget to actually ask the question on the site if you think it has value for future visitors, even if you got the answer in chat already. The Q\&A site is way more accessible and searchable than chat.
* You can ping certain knowledgeable people in chat, if you're specifically interested in what they think about your question. I would only do this if I knew that person well and that they're open to be invited like this. It's not something you should do as a new user, and it's something I'd do *in addition* to posting the question. In general, you want as much visibility to your question as you can get, and Q\&A is much more visible than chat.

But chat is mostly used for other things than Q\&A, e.g. [coordinated moderation](https://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/41570/so-close-vote-reviewers), (as a [side channel](https://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/38/2019/6/3)) for [live events](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/318428/295232), or just to chill.

\#\#\# User: It is clear that Stack Overflow is a community driven network that encourages users to actively answer or ask questions, flag and/or edit them. 

If a user registers interest in a SE site\- answers a single question or two and then loses interest, inherently it means they have no more interest in the particular community.

I think there should be an inactive flag. (just like in golf and a golfer's handicap) If you do not participate actively in the community (no points what so ever) you should not have full rights in that community anymore, until you show particular interest again. (for example \- earning another 150 reputation to become active again)

I would like to discuss the feasibility of implementing this sort of system.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'm strongly disinclined to implement a feature like this for several reasons.

1. If a user only asks two or three questions on a site (let's use [Home Improvement](http://diy.stackexchange.com) as an example) and receives really excellent responses, but then goes inactive for six months, why would deactivating their account help? This is a user who is *more likely* to go out to his friends/neighbors and tell them about the site, how much it helped him/her, and how fast/good the responses were. These are all our core competencies, and creating a punishment for this user would create a certain amount of negative dissonance. I don't like making barriers to entry for a user who could "pay it forward" and thus help *us* out long\-term.
2. Take a user like [Karl Katzke](https://diy.stackexchange.com/users/3450/karl-katzke), a 5k\+ user on DIY who's been largely inactive for the last year or so. He's mentioned that his lack of activity is entirely due to the [demands of his real\-life job](https://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/111?m=5682430#5682430). Users like this are the ones we want to *come back and be welcomed*. Forcing him to take on a penalty for his absence \-\- which was by no means voluntary \-\- isn't fair and doesn't breed goodwill with our community.   

 I'm all for encouraging our top users to stick around \-\- but that's what [the Fanatic badge](https://diy.stackexchange.com/badges/55/fanatic) is for. Forcing a punishment for not showing up to a *volunteer internet site* feels mean\-spirited.
3. Tracking this would be a pain. What would be a "fair" deduction? What period constitutes inactive? Activity levels vary by communities, due to their nature (Gardening and DIY are seasonal, SO and SF are not, academic subjects and Academia.SE have a 75/25 split in their activity over the course of the year) and tracking these would have to be custom per\-site. That's taxing on our system.

ppumpkin, sure, this election is over. But that doesn't make you powerless as a user. Bmitch and Tester101 were flagging, answering well, submitting great edits, and doing all the same things a moderator does even before they had diamonds. You're not exempt from this. Continue to be a star! There will be other elections, and there will be other chances to prove yourself, I can assure you of that!

\#\#\# User: Define a function $F$ on the natural numbers $\\geq 2$ as follows:
Start with $a \\geq 2$ and let $b$ be the smallest prime divisor of $a$ and $c:\=a\+b$ and let $d$ denote the largest prime divisor of $c$. 
Define $F(a):\=c\-d$.
Define the period $p(a)$ of a natural number as $p(a):\= \\inf \\{ i \| 
F^{i}(a)\=F^{i\-1}(a) \\}.$

Here an example:

Let a\=832 with smallest prime divisor 2\.

Then b\=2 and c\=834 with largest prime divisor d\=139\. Then $F(a)$\=834\-139\=695\.

Now $a\_2\=695$ has smallest prime divisor 5 and $c\_2\=700$ has largest prime divisor 7 and thus $F^2(a)\=700\-7\=693$.

Now $a\_3\=693$ has smallest prime divisor 3 and $c\_3\=696$ has largest prime divisor 29 and thus $F^3(a)\=696\-29\=667$.

Now $a\_4\=667$ has smallest prime divisor 23 and $c\_4\=690$ has largest prime divisor 23 and thus $F^4(a)\=667\=F^3(a)$.

> Question: Is there an explicit formula for $p(a)$ or a good bound? Has it been considered before?

For integers smaller than or equal to 50000 the largest period was 16 reached at the three numbers 21404, 25515, 25516\.

It might also be intersting to look at variations of the function $F$. For example one might take first the largest prime divisor and then the smallest (when starting with a non\-prime).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: As defined, $d \\geq b$ , so iterating $F$ will lead to a fixed point $qr$, a product of a prime $q$ which is no larger than any prime factor of $r$ and such that $(r\+1\)$ is $q$\-smooth. Most of the time, $F(a)$ will be odd, and often will be smaller than $a$ by an amount at least as large as $\\sqrt{a}$. This suggests the period of $a$ is $O(\\sqrt{a})$, and probably the period is much smaller.

As $a$ decreases by even numbers, I expect $b$ to be small with a frequency about as expected, meaning that about 7/15 of the values of $b$ will be 3 or 5\. A nice quantity to know is $\\mid \\{ a \\leq n: F(a)\=a\\}\\mid/n$, the density of fixed points. This will likely be near 1/average length of period, but that is another guess. They will be at least as dense as somewhat smooth numbers: for numbers $c$ whose largest prime factor is $q$ and have many small prime factors, $c\-q$ will often be a fixed point for $F$.

Guy's book Unsolved Problems In Number Theory has problems involving iterated number theoretic functions. It would be a good starting point for a literature search on this kind of problem.

Gerhard "Still Studying Dynamics Of Primes" Paseman, 2018\.06\.18\.

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you type

```
command 1 & command 2

```

this is equal to

```
command 1 &
command 2

```

i.e. this will run the first command in background and then runs the second command in foreground. Especially this means, that your `echo "done"` is printed after `command 2` finished even if `command 1` is still running.

You probably want

```
command 1 &
command 2 &
wait
echo "done"

```

This will run both commands in background and wait for both to complete.

---

If you press CTRL\-C this will only send the SIGINT signal to the foreground process, i.e. `command 2` in your version or `wait` in my version.

I would suggest setting a trap like this:

```
#!/bin/bash

trap killgroup SIGINT

killgroup(){
  echo killing...
  kill 0
}

loop(){
  echo $1
  sleep $1
  loop $1
}

loop 1 &
loop 2 &
wait

```

With the trap the SIGINT signal produced by CTRL\-C is trapped and replaced by the `killgroup` function, which kills all those processes.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are working on a bash script that needs to run two long-running commands concurrently and then perform an action after both have completed. Which of the following code snippets would correctly accomplish this task while also allowing for proper termination of both processes if the user interrupts the script with CTRL-C?

A)
```bash
command1 &
command2 &
echo "done"
```

B)
```bash
command1 & command2
echo "done"
```

C)
```bash
trap killgroup SIGINT

killgroup(){
  kill 0
}

command1 &
command2 &
wait
echo "done"
```

D)
```bash
command1 &
wait
command2 &
wait
echo "done"
```

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the correct answer because it incorporates several key elements:

1. It runs both commands in the background using `&`.
2. It uses `wait` to ensure the script doesn't proceed until both background processes are complete.
3. It sets up a trap for the SIGINT signal (sent by CTRL-C), which kills all processes in the process group (kill 0).

Option A would not wait for the commands to finish before printing "done".
Option B would run command1 in the background but command2 in the foreground, not achieving true concurrency.
Option D would run the commands sequentially, not concurrently.

Only option C provides true concurrency, proper waiting, and handles user interruption correctly.

and comment

\#\#\# Top Answer: Suppose train's and track's clocks are set to zero when the first wagon passes by the bench. The clocks of the wagons are syncronized in the train's frame.

In the time $T\_0$, according to the bench clock, the clock in the wagon, that is now passing by, is:
$$T \= T\_0\\frac{1} {\\sqrt{1\-\\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}$$
As the train has velocity $v$, the length from the first wagon to this one is $L\_0 \= vT\_0$ for the bench frame.

The same distance to the first wagon, measured by the train is greater, because it is measured at its own frame. And the formula for length contraction is from the stationary to the moving frame, in this case from the train to the track:
$$L\_0 \= L \\sqrt{1\-\\frac{v^2}{c^2}}$$
So, the velocities are $v$ for both frames.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A train is moving at a constant velocity v relative to a stationary bench on the track. The length of the train in its own rest frame is L. An observer on the bench measures the time T_0 for the entire train to pass by. Which of the following expressions correctly represents the proper time T measured by a clock on the train during this interval?

A) T = T_0 * sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)
B) T = T_0 / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)
C) T = L / (v * sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2))
D) T = L * sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2) / v

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. This problem involves time dilation between the train's frame and the stationary bench frame. The time T_0 measured by the bench observer is the dilated time, while T is the proper time in the train's frame. The time dilation formula relates these as T = T_0 / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2).

Option A is incorrect as it reverses the time dilation formula. 
Option C attempts to use the length contraction formula but incorrectly combines it with time dilation.
Option D uses the length contraction formula but doesn't properly account for time dilation.

The correct answer B properly applies the time dilation formula, showing that the time measured on the train (proper time) is less than the time measured by the stationary observer.

Question: In the given Magento 2 custom module for BMI calculation, which of the following correctly describes the flow of data from the form submission to displaying the result?

A) The form submits data directly to the Result controller, which processes the data and returns a JSON response containing the result HTML.

B) The form submission triggers an AJAX call to the Index controller, which then redirects to the Result controller for processing and displaying the result.

C) The form submits data to the Index controller, which then uses the ResultJsonFactory to return the calculated BMI directly as a JSON response.

D) The form submission triggers an AJAX call to the Result controller, which processes the data, creates a block with the result template, and returns the block HTML as a JSON response.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
The correct flow is described in option D. Let's break it down:

1. The form in calculation.phtml uses JavaScript to submit data via AJAX to the Result controller (Vendor\Module\Controller\Result\Result).
2. The Result controller's execute() method receives the height and weight parameters.
3. It then creates a new block instance, sets the template to result.phtml, and passes the height and weight data to the block.
4. The controller renders the block to HTML and wraps it in a JSON response.
5. The AJAX success callback in the JavaScript receives this JSON response, which contains the rendered HTML of the result.

Options A, B, and C are incorrect because:
A) While close, it implies direct form submission rather than AJAX.
B) Incorrectly involves the Index controller in the process.
C) Incorrectly suggests that the BMI calculation happens in the controller, when in fact the module seems to pass the raw data to the template for processing.

This question tests understanding of Magento 2's controller structure, AJAX interactions, and the flow of data in a custom module.

\#\#\# User: We have a service which is a distributed system running across about 16 machines, each doing different things.

When an operational issue is reported, I would ideally like our dev/ops team to be able to log into all 16 servers at once, with an appropriate terminal arrangement on the screen.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Many settings are stored in property list files in `~/Library/Preferences/`. You can convert them to xml to edit or read them in a text editor:

```
plutil -convert xml1 ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.finder.plist

```

Sandboxed applications use files like `~/Library/Containers/com.apple.TextEdit/Data/Library/Preferences/com.apple.TextEdit.plist`. `find ~/Library/Containers/com.apple.TextEdit -type f` shows all files in the sandbox container.

For example Chrome stores settings in `~/Library/Application Support/Google/Chrome/`.

You can find support files with something like `mdfind TextEdit` or `mdfind com.apple.TextEdit`.

\#\#\# User: Let's have two orthogonal n\-particle quantum states: $\|\\psi \\rangle$ and $\|\\phi \\rangle$. In theory it is always possible to make an unambiguous measurement.

However, things get complicated when one restricts oneself to a certain class of measurements. With so called LOCC (Local Operations and Classical Communication, that is, we have to measure particles separately, but we are allowed to communicate and to have dependence for measurements on the outcomes of previous measurement) still it is possible to unambiguously distinguish any two states (see: Walgate et al., *Local Distinguishability of Multipartite Orthogonal Quantum States*, Phys. Rev. Lett. 85, 23: 4972\-4975 (2000\) [arXiv:quant\-ph/0007098](http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0007098)).

With fixed local operations (and thus classical communications only after all measurements are done) sometimes we can't unambiguously distinguish between $\|\\psi \\rangle$ and $\|\\phi \\rangle$.

* Is there any simple argument why?
* Are there any simple criteria which says which orthogonal states can be unambiguously distinguished with local measurements and communication only after them?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: To keep things simple, let's talk about two\-qubit states.

A single qubit could have an orthonormal basis $\\{\|0\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\\}$. But it could also have a different orthonormal basis $\\{\|\+\\rangle,\|\-\\rangle\\}$, where $$\|\+\\rangle \= \\large(\\normalsize\|0\\rangle \\small\+\\normalsize \|1\\rangle\\large)\\normalsize / \\sqrt{2}$$ $$\|\-\\rangle \= \\large(\\normalsize\|0\\rangle \\small\-\\normalsize \|1\\rangle\\large)\\normalsize / \\sqrt{2}$$

No suppose the two states you're trying to distinguish are: $$\|\\psi\\rangle \= \\large(\\normalsize\|0\\rangle\|0\\rangle \\small\+\\normalsize \|1\\rangle\|\+\\rangle\\large)\\normalsize / \\sqrt{2}$$ and $$\|\\phi\\rangle \= \\large(\\normalsize\|0\\rangle\|1\\rangle \\small\+\\normalsize \|1\\rangle\|\-\\rangle\\large)\\normalsize / \\sqrt{2}$$

Here the first qubit in each term is Alice's and the second qubit in each term is Bob's.  

Let's say Alice does a measurement in the $\\{\|0\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\\}$ basis. After the measurement the state will be projected into a new state, but *which* new state depends on the result of Alice's measurement.  

If Alice observes state $\|0\\rangle$: $$\|\\psi\\rangle \\rightarrow \|0\\rangle\|0\\rangle$$ $$\|\\phi\\rangle \\rightarrow \|0\\rangle\|1\\rangle$$

If Alice observes state $\|1\\rangle$:$$\|\\psi\\rangle \\rightarrow \|1\\rangle\|\+\\rangle$$ $$\|\\phi\\rangle \\rightarrow \|1\\rangle\|\-\\rangle$$

If Bob *knows* Alice observes $\|0\\rangle$, then he can distinguish the two states by making a measurement in the $\\{\|0\\rangle,\|1\\rangle\\}$ basis. Likewise, if Bob *knows* Alice observes $\|1\\rangle$, then he can distinguish the two states by making a measurement in the $\\{\|\+\\rangle,\|\-\\rangle\\}$ basis.  

**But if Bob doesn't know the result of Alice's measurement until *after* he makes his measurement, then he doesn't know *which* measurement to make.**  

If the true state is $\|1\\rangle\|\+\\rangle$ but Bob guesses it's either $\|0\\rangle\|0\\rangle$ or $\|0\\rangle\|1\\rangle$, then he's going to make a measurement in the $\\{\|0\\rangle,\|1\\rangle\\}$ basis. This means he's equally likely to observe $\|0\\rangle$ or $\|1\\rangle$, since the true state of his qubit, $\|\+\\rangle$, is an equal superposition of $\|0\\rangle$ and $\|1\\rangle$. Note that even if the true state of his qubit were $\|\-\\rangle$ (the only other possibility after Alice's measurement), Bob would still have been equally likely to observe $\|0\\rangle$ or $\|1\\rangle$.  

So after comparing results, Alice and Bob realize that Bob's measurement tells them nothing, and moreover the result of Alice's measurement by itself does nothing to distinguish the two initial states.  

**Edit:**  

I'm going to try to give a more general rule for which states Alice and Bob can distinguish with local measurements only (no communication until afterwards.)  

If Alice and Bob aren't going to communicate until their measurements are done, then the combined measurement is effectively chosen before hand. As Frédéric Grosshans points out in his answer, this measurement will be a projection into the eigenbasis of $A \\otimes B$, where $A$ is a local observable that Alice can measure and $B$ is a local observable that Bob can measure.  

If $S\_A$ is the set of eigenstates of $A$, and $S\_B$ is the set of eigenstates of $B$, then the set of eigenstates of $A \\otimes B$ is the direct product (the Cartesian product) of $S\_A$ and $S\_B$.  

As an example, if $S\_A \= S\_B \= \\{\|0\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\\}$, Alice and Bob will only distinguish $\\{\|0\\rangle\|0\\rangle, \|0\\rangle\|1\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\|0\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\|1\\rangle\\}$. If $S\_A \= \\{\|0\\rangle,\|1\\rangle\\}$ and $S\_B \= \\{\|\+\\rangle,\|\-\\rangle\\}$, Alice and Bob will only distinguish $\\{\|0\\rangle\|\+\\rangle, \|0\\rangle\|\-\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\|\+\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\|\-\\rangle\\}$.  

If you have a set like my two entangled states above, or Frédéric Grosshans' four states $\\{\|0\\rangle\|0\\rangle, \|0\\rangle\|1\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\|\+\\rangle, \|1\\rangle\|\-\\rangle\\}$, then there's no choice of $A$ and $B$ that will suffice, because these states aren't in the direct product of the eigenstates of two local measurements.

40.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Alice and Bob are trying to distinguish between two orthogonal two-qubit states:
|ψ⟩ = (|0⟩|0⟩ + |1⟩|+⟩) / √2 and 
|φ⟩ = (|0⟩|1⟩ + |1⟩|-⟩) / √2
If they are restricted to making local measurements without communicating until after both have measured, which of the following statements is true?

A) They can always distinguish the states with certainty by choosing appropriate measurement bases.

B) They can never distinguish the states, regardless of their choice of measurement bases.

C) They can distinguish the states if Alice measures in the {|0⟩, |1⟩} basis and Bob measures in the {|+⟩, |-⟩} basis.

D) They cannot reliably distinguish the states because the eigenbasis of their combined measurement (A ⊗ B) does not include all possible outcomes needed to differentiate |ψ⟩ and |φ⟩.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The key point is that without communication, Alice and Bob must choose their measurement bases independently. Their combined measurement is effectively a projection into the eigenbasis of A ⊗ B, where A is Alice's observable and B is Bob's. This eigenbasis is the direct product of their individual measurement bases. However, the given states |ψ⟩ and |φ⟩ cannot be fully distinguished by any such product basis. This is because they contain terms that are not in the direct product of any two local measurement bases (e.g., |0⟩|0⟩ and |1⟩|+⟩ cannot both be in the same product basis). Therefore, Alice and Bob cannot reliably distinguish these states without communication between measurements.

\#\#\# User: The proliferation of underpopulated SE sites is an item of discussion, but here am concerned about one particular effect: the fracturing of the \[algorithm] tag on SO.

For a long time algorithmic, or partially algorithmic, questions have been asked on SO and tagged with the \[algorithm] tag. There are tens of thousands of such questions on SO. Now with the CS Theory site, what is happening is that random \[algorithm] questions are being migrated to the CS Theory, or just closed as "off topic". There is no rhyme or reason other than random chance. In theory I suppose 90% of the \[algorithm] tagged posts could be moved to CS Theory, but the problem is that SO has nearly 2 million users and practically nobody uses CS Theory. Who wants to post a question to a forum with 11,000 (low time) users when you could post to SO with almost 2,000,000 users? Nobody. Getting migrated to CS is like getting your post deleted.

Also, as an algorithm "answerer" I do not want to visit two different forums. I do not want to be switching back and forth. Also I DEFINITELY do not want my badge/rep efforts to be split between two forums. I want my rep to be on ONE site, SO, because that is where I am asking my questions, which are often not algorithm related.

I used to paticipate in a machining forum and posted to General a set of really interesting photos that would be of general interest to machinists and the moderator force moved my post to the "fabrication" sub forum that had literally \<1% of the population of the general forum just because some of the photos were tangentially fabrication related. It was more or less equivalent to deleting my post, that I spent a LOT of time on. I stopped using that forum.

I am wondering if anybody agrees with me that this is a serious problem that is causing fragmentation in posts in the \[algorithm] tag and what we can do about it?

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\- EXAMPLE

To provide a concrete example, here is some guy's post: [TSP question post on SO that got migrated](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/12485/evolutionary-algorithm-for-the-physical-travelling-salesman-problem). This one actually got migrated to "Computer Science", but just as well similar posts are getting migrated to CS Theory. Why this one got migrated, but 10 others very similar didn't, who knows? In my view this post was a completely legitimate \[algorithm] post that could have, and should have been answered on SO.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: From their [about](https://cstheory.stackexchange.com/about) page:

> Theoretical Computer Science Stack Exchange is a question and answer site for
>  **researchers** in theoretical computer science and related fields.

There's a lot less overlap between Stack Overflow and CS Theory than some people seem to realize, even when there are tags that overlap. Very few of the [algorithm](/questions/tagged/algorithm "show questions tagged 'algorithm'") questions on Stack Overflow would be suitable for CS Theory. They are just not research\-level problems, so should not be migrated.
